extendedContent.title: Description and Nature
extendedContent.content:
The Hand of Glory (from French "main de gloire" or corrupted from "mandragore"/mandrake)
                    is one of the most infamous magical objects in European occult tradition. This gruesome
                    artifact consists of the severed, pickled, and dried hand of an executed criminal, typically
                    one hanged at a crossroads, fashioned into a candleholder or itself used as a candle.
                
                
                    According to folklore, when the fingers were lit (or when a candle made from the criminal's
                    fat was placed in the hand), the Hand of Glory possessed the power to paralyze all who
                    beheld its light and to open any lock it touched. This made it the legendary tool of
                    burglars and thieves throughout medieval and early modern Europe.

Traditional Preparation
                
                    The grimoire traditions provide detailed (and gruesome) instructions for creating a Hand
                    of Glory. The hand had to be severed from a hanged criminal while still on the gibbet,
                    preferably during an eclipse or at a crossroads. It was then wrapped in a piece of the
                    corpse's shroud, squeezed to drain remaining blood, and pickled in an earthen vessel
                    with various salts and peppers for a fortnight.
                
                
                    After pickling, the hand was dried in an oven with vervain and fern, then fashioned
                    into a candle holder. A candle was made from the criminal's fat, virgin wax, and
                    sesame oil (or alternatively, the fingers themselves were set alight). The resulting
                    artifact was believed to be virtually unstoppable in its magical effects.
                

                Countermeasures
                
                    Folk tradition also preserved methods to defend against the Hand of Glory:
                
                
                    Anointing the threshold with an ointment made from the gall of a black cat, owl fat, and blood
                    Blood from a screech owl was said to neutralize its effects
                    Milk was believed to be the only substance that could extinguish its flames
                    Keeping consecrated objects or religious items in the home
extendedContent.title: Creation and Ritual

extendedContent.content:
Several alleged Hands of Glory have survived as museum curiosities, most notably the
                    specimen at the Whitby Museum in North Yorkshire, England. This dried hand, discovered
                    in a cottage wall in the early 20th century, dates to approximately the 18th century
                    and represents one of the few physical examples of this legend made real.
                
                
                    Court records from the 17th and 18th centuries occasionally mention criminals found
                    in possession of "mummified hands" or similar items, suggesting that some individuals
                    genuinely believed in and attempted to create these talismans for criminal purposes.
